name: Yann LeCun
content:
LLaMA is a collection of foundation LLMs from 7B to 65B parameters.
They have been trained on trillions of tokens from publicly available datasets
- LLaMA-13B outperforms GPT-3 (175B) on most benchmarks
- LLaMA-65B is competitive with the best models, Chinchilla70B and PaLM-540B

name: Yann LeCun
content:
LLaMA is a new *open-source*, high-performance large language model from Meta AI - FAIR.

Meta is committed to open research and releases all the models the research community under a GPL v3 license.

- Paper: https://research.facebook.com/publications/llama-open-and-efficient-foundation-language-models/…
- Github: https://github.com/facebookresearch/llama…

Clearly, there are generative models that are not used to "generate" anything complicated.
For example, any classifier that uses Bayes rule P(y|x) = P(x|y)P(y) / P(x).
The P(x|y) model is generative.

Embeddings are hidden.

name: Yann LeCun

You could.
In that case, "generative" would not just characterize the architecture but the combination of the architecture and the inference procedure.
It's like a graphical model / factor graphs: you infer the unknown variables by finding the value that maximizes the likelihood.

name: Yann LeCun
content:
Joint Embedding Architectures (e.g. Siamese nets) are non generative.
They can capture dependencies between x and y but cannot "generate" y from x, and certainly cannot provide an estimate p(y|x).
Almost all successful SSL methods in image recognition use JEA or JEPA.

name: Yann LeCun
content:
FAIR receives headcount, operating budget, & computing investment.
It's a bad idea to link research funding to revenue impact for 2 reasons:
(1) the impact is indirect, often months or years after the research
(2) it gives an incentive to work on incremental short-term projects.

name: Yann LeCun
content:
For FAIR, the value comes from projects with product groups to create new products and services or improve existing ones.
This pays for research several times over.

name: Yann LeCun
content:
Crypto bro: AI labs should stop publishing useless papers and make products that increase shareholder value.
Me: There would be no new product without the research published in those papers. New products aren't pulled out of thin air, unlike cryptocurrency value.

Light pollution is horrible in my NJ suburb.
So I use a narrowband filter that only lets through 4 wavelengths that many nebulae emit (ionized hydrogen alpha & beta, oxygen III, and sulfur II).
This was shot with a quad-band filter and a color camera.

My picture was shot with a narrowband filter to reduce the effects of light pollution (which is pretty awful in my NJ suburb).

name: Yann LeCun
content:
1. Select the good shots.
2. Align the shots and average them.
3. Manually correct the colors in the resulting image.
#1 is done with a custom Python script.
#2 is done automatically by a custom PyTorch script.
#3 is done manually in Gimp.
It takes maybe 20 minutes overall.

2400 light-years away.
Shot in June 2021 in my NJ backyard.

Filter: Radian Triad quad narrow band.
Exposures: 65 shots, 300 seconds each.

Regarding weight sharing, or lack thereof in biology: you don't need weight sharing if the training is essentially self-supervised.
Repeated feature detectors will naturally emerge from self-supervised learning because the local statistics of images are essentially stationary.

name: Yann LeCun

You can easily do that within a corporate research lab because your research can pay for itself several times over through product impact.
This is the model used by Meta with FAIR.
It is similar to the model used by Bell Labs, IBM Research, Xerox PARC, and MSR in the old days.

name: Yann LeCun
content:
It's not necessarily about greed.
If you want to have a large and positive impact, you need human and material resources.
To attract the best scientists and engineers, you need to pay them well.
To pay for computational resources, you need revenue or investment.

name: Yann LeCun
content:
Excellent paper in which the word "criti-hype" is coined.
Criti-hype designates the kind of academic and non-academic work that magnifies the imagined dangers of a new technology, feeding on and mirroring the hype from the advocates of said technology.

name: Yann LeCun

I do not conflate RL with policy gradient.
But I *do* complain when people conflate RL with black-box optimization.
I also find strange that people use RL in situations where optimal control is applicable i..e. where you can construct or learn a model & a differentiable objective

name: Yann LeCun

My position has been clear & unchanged.
I have defended LLMs as writing aids. I still do.
I have also said that LLMs are making stuff up.
I said that this will not destroy society.
I have also said that LLMs don't take us any closer to human-level AI.

Reasoning generally involves a variable and potentially very large number of steps.

14. Unlike what the most acerbic critics of Galactica have claimed
- LLMs *are* being used as writing aids.
- They *will not* destroy the fabric of society by causing the mindless masses to believe their made-up nonsense.
- People will use them for what they are helpful with.

name: Yann LeCun
content:
13. Why do LLMs appear much better at generating code than generating general text?
Because, unlike the real world, the universe that a program manipulates (the state of the variables) is limited, discrete, deterministic, and fully observable.
The real world is none of that.

name: Yann LeCun
content:
Code generation is easier because, unlike the real world, the underlying reality of code is simple, discrete, deterministic and fully observable.
And there is a relatively small number of basic concepts that cover most of it.

name: Yann LeCun
content: Absolutely not.

name: Yann LeCun
content:
It saves a lot typing and may improve your style.
Also relieves you from the fear of the white page.
Not mentioning that it's a big help for non-native speakers and people who find writing painful.

BUT your hands must remain on the keyboard at all times.

name: Yann LeCun

name: Yann LeCun

I have been consistent while:
9. defending Galactica as a scientific writing aid.
10. Warning folks that AR-LLMs make stuff up and should not be used to get factual advice.
11. Warning that only a small superficial portion of human knowledge can ever be captured by LLMs.

name: Yann LeCun

6. Current LLMs should be used as writing aids, not much more.
7. Marrying them with tools such as search engines is highly non trivial.
8. There *will* be better systems that are factual, non toxic, and controllable. They just won't be auto-regressive LLMs.

name: Yann LeCun
content:
My unwavering opinion on current (auto-regressive) LLMs
1. They are useful as writing aids.
2. They are "reactive" & don't plan nor reason.
3. They make stuff up or retrieve stuff approximately.
4. That can be mitigated but not fixed by human feedback.
5. Better systems will come

If you want the system to start from scratch and learn the world model while attempting to solve the problem, then you are in RL-land.

name: Yann LeCun
content:
If your world model is accurate, i.e. if it knows the map, and knows you need a key to open a door, then it's just planning. 
In this case it is particularly simple because the state graph is small and the actions discrete.
You could just use A* or something.

name: Yann LeCun
content:
If you need to do planning, just do planning.
No need for RL.
That's optimal control if the state and/or action space is continuous.
You only need RL for 2 things:
(1) if your objective function is unknown
(2) if your model of the world needs to be learned by taking actions.

John Bridle, who coined the word "softmax", now wishes he had called it "softargmax".

He coined the term while working on a paper published in 1989 in Neural Computation in which he describes the "alphanet" model that makes a hidden Markov model look like a recurrent neural net.
